references: One efficient way to scale up a segmentation model is through multi-dataset training, which involves training a single model to perform accurately across various datasets. However, as we increase the number of classes in such training, we often face label space inconsistencies. Our goal is to facilitate multi-dataset training while accommodating these inconsistencies. A straightforward approach, similar to that in [68], would be to condition the decoder of an existing MaskFormer [10] model with the label space. However, our early experiments showed that this method did not significantly improve upon the baseline MaskFormer model. (Tab. 1 and Fig. 4) We believe this is due to two primary reasons: Firstly, conditioning the MaskFormer decoder on a per-dataset label space restricts the model from understanding novel combinations of categories from different datasets. During inference, the model struggles with new label spaces it did not encounter during training. Secondly, this approach does not adequately address the issue of inconsistent annotations in the training data. For instance, when the mask of “person” overlaps with the mask of “pants”, the model’s confidence in these regions diminishes, resulting in ambiguous predictions (see Fig. 1).

Tab. 1 demonstrates our results on the mixed-label space benchmarks CIHPPP{}_{\textrm{P}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT P end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT, CIHPMM{}_{\textrm{M}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT M end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT, CSPPP{}_{\textrm{P}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT P end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT and CSPMM{}_{\textrm{M}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT M end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT. For each method, we evaluate two models trained on dataset groups D2 and D3, respectively. Our method RESI outperforms all baselines on all four benchmarks.

references: One efficient way to scale up a segmentation model is through multi-dataset training, which involves training a single model to perform accurately across various datasets. However, as we increase the number of classes in such training, we often face label space inconsistencies. Our goal is to facilitate multi-dataset training while accommodating these inconsistencies. A straightforward approach, similar to that in [68], would be to condition the decoder of an existing MaskFormer [10] model with the label space. However, our early experiments showed that this method did not significantly improve upon the baseline MaskFormer model. (Tab. 1 and Fig. 4) We believe this is due to two primary reasons: Firstly, conditioning the MaskFormer decoder on a per-dataset label space restricts the model from understanding novel combinations of categories from different datasets. During inference, the model struggles with new label spaces it did not encounter during training. Secondly, this approach does not adequately address the issue of inconsistent annotations in the training data. For instance, when the mask of “person” overlaps with the mask of “pants”, the model’s confidence in these regions diminishes, resulting in ambiguous predictions (see Fig. 1).

Tab. 1 demonstrates our results on the mixed-label space benchmarks CIHPPP{}_{\textrm{P}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT P end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT, CIHPMM{}_{\textrm{M}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT M end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT, CSPPP{}_{\textrm{P}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT P end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT and CSPMM{}_{\textrm{M}}start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT M end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT. references: In addition to panoptic, instance, and semantic segmentation, we evaluate the Panoptic Instance Quality (PIQ) on the Cityscapes Panoptic Parts benchmark, which features overlapping masks for “thing” categories. As detailed in Sec. 4.1 Benchmarking Image Segmentation, our aim is to combine the benefits of per-pixel classification from panoptic segmentation with the allowance for overlapping masks in instance segmentation, thereby enhancing the accuracy measurement of a model in a unified and scalable manner. Tab. 2 demonstrates that RESI outperforms all baselines.

references: We next investigate the impact of different model components. We evaluate ESF-OMI on the proposed model RESI and one baseline, M2F+LE. As shown in Tab. 4, the proposed inference algorithm ESF-OMI is crucial when handling semantically overlapping label spaces. For non-overlapping spaces, both methods perform similarly, with the original algorithm [10] having a slight advantage. However, the post-processing algorithm alone does not account for the entire performance gap between RESI and the baselines in Tab. 1(a). Even with the original post-processing, RESI outperforms the baselines. Additionally, we assess per-dataset label-space performance in Tab. 3, demonstrating LSQE’s effectiveness in resolving semantic inconsistencies during multi-dataset training.

Next, we evaluate all models on the label spaces of the individual datasets for each of the three training dataset groups, D1, D2, D3. As shown in Tab. 3, all four models perform similarly well across most benchmarks. This demonstrates that our adapted inference algorithm, which runs the decoder multiple times (Sec. 3.4), remains effective in this setting while clearly outperforming the baselines in the mixed-label space setting (Tab. 1(a)). Notably, even during per-dataset label space evaluation, the decoder in RESI runs multiple times if two of the training datasets share the same category. We focus on PQ in this setting to facilitate comparison with prior works that only conducted per-dataset evaluations.

One standout result in Tab. 3 is the significantly higher PQ of RESI on the benchmarks CS and CSP. The reason is that in dataset group D3, the training images are exactly the same but the annotations are different (whole objects versus parts in CityScapes [12]). This seems to confuse all baseline models while RESI can handle this. Fig. 4 shows some examples. Note that this is even a practical use case where an existing annotated dataset is extended with new labels but not for all images to save cost.

S4.T4.4.caption: Table 4 :  Ablation study of different model components in RESI on average PQ. LSQE enables the model to generate diverse masks from various input categories, even in the presence of potential semantic conflicts. However, this diversity may sometimes result in a performance drop due to confusion and overlap, as seen in the second row for CSP P P {}_{\textrm{P}} start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT P end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT  and CSP M M {}_{\textrm{M}} start_FLOATSUBSCRIPT M end_FLOATSUBSCRIPT . ESF-OMI effectively refines the masks produced by LSQE, leading to superior performance when both modules operate in tandem (last row).
references: We next investigate the impact of different model components. We evaluate ESF-OMI on the proposed model RESI and one baseline, M2F+LE. As shown in Tab. 4, the proposed inference algorithm ESF-OMI is crucial when handling semantically overlapping label spaces. For non-overlapping spaces, both methods perform similarly, with the original algorithm [10] having a slight advantage. However, the post-processing algorithm alone does not account for the entire performance gap between RESI and the baselines in Tab. 1(a). Even with the original post-processing, RESI outperforms the baselines. Additionally, we assess per-dataset label-space performance in Tab. 3, demonstrating LSQE’s effectiveness in resolving semantic inconsistencies during multi-dataset training.

references: To do inference with LSQEs, we first find the closest match between each test class embedding ec,∗Tsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑇𝑐e^{T}_{c,*}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the training class embeddings {ec,kT}subscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑇𝑐𝑘\{e^{T}_{c,k}\}{ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Each match reveals a label-space specific index k𝑘kitalic_k, which we collect to the set D={k}𝐷𝑘D=\{k\}italic_D = { italic_k }. This set can have at most K𝐾Kitalic_K elements. If any test-time class ec,∗Tsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑇𝑐e^{T}_{c,*}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has equal similarity to multiple classes from different datasets, we include both label-space specific indices. This happens when multiple datasets share the same category, like “person”. We then run the decoder |D|𝐷|D|| italic_D | times with the corresponding LSQEs ekLsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝐿𝑘e^{L}_{k}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and collect the N⋅|D|⋅𝑁𝐷N\cdot|D|italic_N ⋅ | italic_D | predictions consisting of masks and embedding vectors eiIsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝐼𝑖e^{I}_{i}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This strategy is highly effective in preserving label-space consistency and accuracy but can increase the inference time by a small factor (see Tab. 5). The per-prediction classification is computed as the dot product between eiIsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝐼𝑖e^{I}_{i}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and all test-time class embeddings ec,∗Tsubscriptsuperscript𝑒𝑇𝑐e^{T}_{c,*}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Fig. 2 illustrates the inference process.
